title: Median, Ulnar, and Radial Pathways
summary: Trace the three major nerves and arteries through the hand, linking surface landmarks to sensory maps and anastomoses.
high_yield: Median nerve: recurrent motor branch + common digital nerves; emphasize carpal tunnel course.
Ulnar nerve and artery: Guyon’s canal, superficial vs. deep branches—connect to handlebar palsy.
Radial artery dives through anatomical snuffbox into deep palmar arch; radial nerve splits superficial (sensory) vs. deep (PIN).
pitfalls: Students forget the palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve bypasses the tunnel—call it out.
Clarify the ulnar nerve innervates most intrinsic muscles (deep branch) to avoid underestimating deficits.

animation_timeline.narration: Draw the median nerve entering the carpal tunnel, splitting into recurrent motor and digital branches with sensory map overlay.
animation_timeline.visual: Palmar view with yellow tracing, shaded sensory distribution, callout for palmar cutaneous branch.

animation_timeline.narration: Layer on the ulnar nerve and artery through Guyon’s canal, branching into superficial sensory and deep motor pathways.
animation_timeline.visual: Medial wrist inset showing canal boundaries; animations for superficial vs. deep arches.

animation_timeline.narration: Conclude with radial artery through the snuffbox forming deep palmar arch; add radial nerve superficial branch sensory map.
animation_timeline.visual: Dorsolateral view with artery loop and nerve sensory shading over dorsal thumb/index.
